analytic.title: Systems & Control Letters

biblStruct.note: Received 24 November 2010 Received in revised form 16 October 2011 Accepted 23 October 2011

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Formation control problem Multi-agent system Iterative learning control (ILC) Nonlinear dynamics Switching topology

div.p: In this paper, an efficient framework is proposed to the formation control problem of multiple agents with unknown nonlinear dynamics, by means of the iterative learning approach. In particular, a distributed Dtype iterative learning scheme is developed for the multi-agent system with switching topology, whose switching time and sequence are allowed to be varied at different iterations according to the actual trajectories of agents, and a sufficient condition is derived to ensure that the desired formation can be always preserved from the initial starting location to the final one after some iterations. Simulation results are provided to verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In recent years, cooperative control of multi-agent systems has been widely studied due to the development of advanced theory of complex systems and its broad applications in many fields including biology, physics, robotics, vehicles and control engineering. Problems of consensus, flocking, formation, rendezvous, coverage and swarming are some important research issues, and the common task is to develop distributed schemes or protocols to ensure the realization of complicated global goals. In particular, the formation control problem is to find a coordinated scheme for networks of multiple agents such that they would reach and maintain some desired, possibly time-varying formation or group configuration. Applications of formation control can be found in the automotive and aerospace areas, ranging from assembling structures, exploration of unknown environments, navigation in hostile environments, to cooperative transportation tasks.

In the literature, researchers proposed many approaches for the multi-agent system to achieve final formation from its initial configuration, roughly categorized as leader-following strategy [1,2], behavior-based approach [3,4] and virtual structure method [5][6][7], to name a few. In the virtual structure approach, the formation is treated as a single rigid body, and then the motion of each agent can be derived from the trajectory of a corresponding point on the structure. In addition, some researchers also applied consensus protocols to the formation control of multiple agents by appropriately choosing information states on which consensus is reached [8][9][10][11], where consensus means that all agents agree upon some certain quantities of interest [12,13]. For example, in [8], variants of a consensus algorithm were used to tackle the formation control problem of second-order multi-agent systems, and the accurate formation was proved to be asymptotically achieved in the case that information flow was unidirectional. Xiao et al. [11] applied the proposed nonlinear consensus protocol to the formation control, including time-invariant formation, timevarying formation and trajectory tracking, respectively. It turned out that all agents could achieve the expected formation after a finite time.

In the related studies on formation control, the dynamics of agents are usually assumed to be linear and known. Actually, almost all the physical plants contain nonlinearities, and it is difficult to obtain the exact system model. Therefore, studies on formation control of multi-agent systems with unknown nonlinear dynamics are of great necessity. More importantly, in the above research papers, one can only ensure the realization of desired formation when time converges to infinity or after a finite time. However, in some practical applications, all agents have to maintain the desired relative positions that determine the formation structure, during the overall process of executing a given repetitive task, such as cooperative transportation of heavy load [14] and satellite formation keeping [15]. To be specific, in the industrial field, when a group of vehicles or mobile robots cooperate to transport a very large and heavy object in a given formation repetitively, they must maintain the desired formation during the whole transportation process, from the prescribed starting location to the destination.

Recently, Ahn and Chen [16] have overcome the above two limitations by applying the iterative learning control (ILC) approach [17][18][19][20] to study the formation control problem of multi-agent systems with unknown nonlinear dynamics. It was proved that all agents could keep a desired formation from the initial location to the final one after iterative learning. However, only the formation of cyclic structure was considered in their paper, and how to realize a more general formation deserves further investigation. Secondly, the interaction topology among agents was assumed to be fixed in [16], and the ILC-based formation control for switching networks of multiple agents has not been considered yet. Moreover, the desired relative positions or outputs were only set to two directly connected agents in [16], to describe a prescribed formation configuration. Then, the third problem is how to make the formation description independent of the interaction topology, which is more applicable and particularly essential for handling the switching topology case.

Inspired by [16], we employ the ILC approach to deal with the formation control of general configuration for the multiagent system with unknown nonlinear dynamics and switching interaction topology, and explicitly address the above three problems. Firstly, by using the virtual structure method or introducing a ''virtual leader'', the formation control of any given structure is transformed into a suitably defined consensus problem. This framework of formation description turns out to be independent of the time-varying interaction topology. Then, in order to exploit the ILC method, the above consensus problem is further converted into a stability control problem over finite time intervals, to which a distributed D-type iterative learning scheme is proposed. To proceed, a convergence analysis of the obtained ILC process is presented to get a sufficient condition in the form of matrix norm, such that all agents can keep the desired formation during the whole finite-time motion or operation process. Finally, simulation results show that under the proposed scheme, a nonlinear multi-agent system can preserve a desired formation during the whole movement process after a finite number of iterations. It deserves pointing out that the ILC approach is not applicable to the multi-agent coordination system that cannot operate repetitively.
Notations: 1 and 0 denote the column vectors of appropriate dimensions whose elements are all ones and all zeros, respectively;
I n and 0 n (0 n×m ) denote the n × n identity matrix and the n × n (n × m) zero matrix, respectively; notation D + stands for the right derivative operator of a function matrix.

div.head: Problem statement
div.p: Consider a multi-agent system consisting of n agents with the jth one governed by the following nonlinear dynamics

where x j (t) ∈ R m is the state of agent j at time instant t, u j (t) ∈ R m 1 is the control input or scheme, and f (x j (t)) is an unknown nonlinear Lipschitz continuous functional in terms of x j (t). The objective is to design a distributed scheme for the multi-agent system (1) such that the accurate formation can be always kept among agents during the overall motion process.

For the simple cyclic formation addressed in [16], formation errors can be easily defined by the difference values between the real-time relative outputs and the desired ones of any two connected agents. Then, the purpose is to design schemes to drive the above formation errors converge to zero. However, for a general formation configuration whose local connection is tight, irregular and even time-varying, as considered here, the formation error defined in [16] is inapplicable. In view of this, a desired formation is described by the relative positions of all agents to a common non-physical virtual leader. To be specific, we say that the multi-agent system (1) achieves the desired formation if and only if

where d j (t) represents the desired relative state of agent j to the common virtual leader, 0 and T are the initial and the stop times, respectively. From (2), it is obvious that the desired relative state from the jth to the lth agents is d l (t) -d j (t). Here, we suppose that the multi-agent system operates repetitively to achieve the desired formation over a fixed time interval, motivated by its practical applications presented in the introduction. For simplicity of analysis, it is henceforth assumed that there is no initial formation error, i.e., the initial state condition satisfies (2).
Remark 1. Model (1) covers the first-and second-order linear dynamic systems studied in [2,8] by letting x j (t) = r j (t) and
div.formula: x j (t) = [r T j (t) v T j (t)]
div.p: T , respectively, where r j (t) and v j (t) are the position and the velocity of agent j. For the second-order multiagent system, the desired relative state of agent j is taken as
div.formula: d j (t) = [d T r j (t)0 T
div.p: ] T with d r j (t) being its desired relative position to the virtual leader, which implies that the group eventually moves with a common velocity and meanwhile preserves the accurate formation.

Directed graphs in algebraic graph theory are applied to model the interaction topologies among agents. Let G = (V, E , A) be a weighted directed graph of order n with the set of nodes V = {v 1 , . . . , v n }, the set of directed edges E ⊆ V × V, and a weighted adjacency matrix A = [a jl ] with nonnegative adjacency weights a jl . In graph G, the edge (v l , v j ), from v l to v j , represents that information is transmitted from agents l to j. It is stipulated the nonnegative adjacency weight associated with (v l , v j ) is a jl , which is positive if and only if (v l , v j ) ∈ E . Then the set of neighbors of agent j is denoted by [0, ∞)  → {1, . . . , M} M is defined, where M ∈ Z + denotes the total number of possible interaction graphs. Note that σ (t) is a right-hand continuous function. In this paper, each switching graph is assumed to have a spanning tree.
div.formula: N j = {v l ∈ V : (v l , v j ) ∈ E }.

div.head: Problem reformulation
div.p: In order to use the ILC theory, we have to transform the formation control problem into an asymptotical stability control problem over a finite time interval. To achieve this, we first reformulate the formation control problem as a consensus problem.
Define the state error of agent j as
Then the desired formation (2) can be rewritten as
Thus, the accurate formation is guaranteed by the consensus of all agents on their state errors, defined as in (3). In this way, the formation control problem is reformulated as a consensus
div.formula: problem. Denote e(t) = [e T 1 (t) • • • e T n (t)] T ∈ R nm .
div.p: Now, the task is to realize the consensus of all agents on their state errors e j (t) (j ∈ N ), that is, find ways such that e(t) converges to 1 ⊗ e 0 (t), where e 0 (t) ∈ R m is the agreement state error.

Unfortunately, the ILC method cannot be directly used to solve the above consensus problem, since it usually aims at the monotone convergence analysis of tracking error to zero based on the contraction-mapping theory. Therefore, in order to utilize the ILC theory, we must convert the nonzero equilibrium 1 ⊗ e 0 (t)
to the origin, that is, transform the consensus problem into an asymptotical stability problem of another system. To this end, we adopt the tree-type transformation proposed in [13].

div.head: Tree-type transformation
div.p: Given a directed tree T = (V, E (T ), A(T )), the so-called treetype transformation L T , related to the directed tree T , is presented as follows:
div.formula: y jl (t) = e j (t) -e l (t), (v j , v l ) ∈ E (T ).(5)
div.p: Set Y T as a column vector with elements y jl (t) defined by (5), which can describe disagreements between agents and is called a disagreement vector. Obviously, Y T ∈ R (n-1)×m , since T is a directed tree with n nodes. It has been demonstrated that the consensus is reached on e j (t) (j = 1, . . . , n) if and only if Y T = 0.
Accordingly, the consensus problem is equivalently transformed into the stability analysis of the origin of another reduced-order system.

From Proposition 1 in [13], we know that the transformation (5) based on any directed tree is equivalent for studying the consensus problem. Without loss of generality, we take a particular directed tree T 0 with the root v 1 and all the other nodes v 2 , . . . , v n being its children. Based on T 0 , conduct the tree-type transformation on e(t) as follows:

In light of the above analysis, the following task is to design distributed schemes for the multi-agent system (1) such that
According to Remark 2 of [13], we have:

div.head: Lemma 1. The matrix -ELG is Hurwitz stable if and only if the
div.p: directed graph G has a spanning tree, where L is the Laplacian of graph G.

div.head: Iterative learning scheme and convergence analysis
Distributed scheme design
div.p: Based on the previous preparations, we will utilize the iterative learning approach to make (10) satisfied. Rewrite the dynamic Eq. (1) as ẋi,j (t) = f (x i,j (t)) + B(t)u i,j (t), i = 0, 1, 2, . . .
where i is the discrete-iteration index, x i,j (t) and u i,j (t) are the state and the scheme of agent j at iteration i. The compact form of iterative system (11) is
div.formula: ẋi (t) = F (x i (t)) + (I n ⊗ B(t))u i (t),(12)
div.p: where column vectors x i (t) ∈ R nm and u i (t) ∈ R nm 1 are formed by x i,j (t) and u i,j (t) (j = 1, . . . , n), respectively, and
div.formula: F (x i (t)) = [f T (x i,1 (t)) • • • f T (x i,n (t))] T .
div.p: Combining with the iteration index i and noticing that the desired formation is fixed at every iteration, the variables in ( 3) and ( 6) become
and

and the corresponding variable vectors of multi-agent system at iteration i are e i (t) ∈ R nm and y i (t) ∈ R (n-1)m , respectively. In the scheme design of any agent j at iteration i + 1, besides the previous control scheme u i,j (t), only the information of its neighbors and itself at iteration i can be exploited. Meanwhile, the interaction graphs will switch according to the actual motions of all agents, and the switching time and sequence differ from trial to trial. Then, combining with the ILC theory, we propose the following distributed D-type iterative learning scheme
div.formula: u i+1,j (t) = u i,j (t) + Γ - l∈N i,j (t) a i,jl (t)(ė i,l (t) -ėi,j (t))(15)
div.p: that can be written in the compact form:
div.formula: u i+1 (t) = u i (t) -(L σ i (t) ⊗ Γ )ė i (t),(16)
div.p: where Γ ∈ R m 1 ×m is an undetermined gain matrix, N i,j (t) is the neighbor set of agent j at time instant t for iteration i, L σ i (t) is the Laplacian of graph G σ i (t) whose positive weights on edges are a i,jl (t), and σ i (t) is the switching signal function of interaction graphs at iteration i. It deserves noticing that the matrix L σ i (t) is piecewise-constant, that is, it is constant during any two successive switching time instants.
div.formula: Definition 1. For iteration i, {(t i k , s i k )|s i k ∈ M, k ∈ {0, 1, . . . , M i }; t i 0 = 0, t i M i +1 = T } is called the switching sequence of switching signal σ i (t), if(1)
σ i (t - i k ) ̸ = σ i (t + i k ) (2) σ i (t) = σ i (t + i k ) = s i k , t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), k = 0, 1, . . . , M i .

div.head: Convergence analysis
div.p: According to Section 2, the desired formation described by (2) is equivalent to the convergence of y i (t) to zero for all t ∈ [0, T ]. Therefore, the remaining work is to find conditions such that y i (t) converges to zero monotonically as a function of iteration i. To this end, the relation formula between y i+1 (t) and y i (t) needs to be calculated for any two contiguous iterations, from which the formation condition can be derived by guaranteeing ‖y i+1 (t)‖ < ‖y i (t)‖. Noticing that the desired separation states d j (t) (j = 1, . . . , n) are fixed during every iteration, we get
where δ i,j (t) is denoted by
Since ( 17) holds for j = 1, . . . , n -1, it is immediate that
where
div.formula: δ i (t) = [δ T i,1 (t) • • • δ T i,n-1 (t)] T = (E ⊗ I m )x i (t)(20)
div.p: with E given by (9). From ( 12) and ( 20), it follows that
div.formula: δi (t) = (E ⊗ I m )ẋ i (t) = (E ⊗ I m )F (x i (t)) + (E ⊗ B(t))u i (t). (21
div.p: Using the notation
div.formula: Φ i (τ ) = D + (EL σ i (τ ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ ) (22)
div.p: and assuming no initial formation error, one can obtain
div.formula: y i+1 (t) -y i (t) = ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ + ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ B(τ ))[u i+1 (τ ) -u i (τ )]dτ = ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ + ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ B(τ ))(-L σ i (τ ) ⊗ Γ )ė i (τ )dτ = ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ -(EL σ i (t) ⊗ B(t)Γ )e i (t) + ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ(23)
div.p: by ( 19), ( 21) and ( 16), where the fact
div.formula: D + [(EL σ i (τ ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ )e i (τ )] = (EL σ i (τ ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ )ė i (τ ) + Φ i (τ )e i (τ )
div.p: and the assumption e i (0) = 0 are used in the third step.
To proceed, we will show an important lemma, which is necessary for establishing the accurate formation condition for switching networks.
div.formula: Lemma 2. For ∀t ∈ [0, T ], it is satisfied that ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ = ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ . (24
div.p: Proof. From (14), we know

By Definition 1, during each time interval [t i k , t i k+1 ), the Laplacian of interaction graph is always L s i k . Thus, for ∀τ ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), D + (EL σ i (τ ) ) = 0 (n-1)×n holds, from which and (25) it yields that
div.formula: Φ i (τ )e i (τ ) = Φ i (τ )[1 ⊗ e i,1 (τ ) + (G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )] = Φ i (τ )(1 ⊗ e i,1 (τ )) + Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ ) = [D + (EL σ i (τ ) ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ + EL σ i (τ ) ⊗ D + (B(τ )Γ )] × (1 ⊗ e i,1 (τ )) + Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ ) = [EL σ i (τ ) ⊗ D + (B(τ )Γ )](1 ⊗ e i,1 (τ )) + Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ ) = Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ ), τ ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), (26
div.p: where L σ i (τ ) 1 = 0 is used in the last step. For any t ∈ [0, T ] at iteration i, the switching time instants contained inside [0, t) are denoted by t i 0 , . . . , t i M(t) . Then, incorporating with (26), we derive
div.formula: ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ = ∫ t i 1 0 Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ + • • • + ∫ t i M(t) t i M(t)-1 Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ + ∫ t t i M(t) Φ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ = ∫ t i 1 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ + • • • + ∫ t i M(t) t i M(t)-1 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ + ∫ t t i M(t) Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ = ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ ,(27)
div.p: which completes the proof. Now, substituting (25) and ( 24) into (23) leads to
div.formula: y i+1 (t) -y i (t) = ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ -(EL σ i (t) ⊗ B(t)Γ )[1 ⊗ e i,1 (t) + (G ⊗ I m )y i (t)] + ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ = ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ -(EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ )y i (t) + ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ ,(28)
div.p: from which it yields
div.formula: y i+1 (t) = (I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ )y i (t) + ∫ t 0 (E ⊗ I m )[F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ + ∫ t 0 Φ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ .(29)
div.p: In the following, we will give the main result by following the lines of proof in [14]. To show the convergence of y i (t) to zero as iteration index i increases, the definition of λ-norm is introduced.
Definition 2. Given a vector function h : [0, T ]  → R n , its λ-norm is defined by
where ‖ • ‖ is any generic norm defined in the vector space R n .
It is obvious that the following relationship holds between the λ-norm and the norm ‖ • ‖ taken in Definition 2:
div.formula: ‖h‖ λ ≤ sup t∈[0,T ] ‖h(t)‖ ≤ e λT ‖h‖ λ .
div.p: In this paper, we define the ∞-norm of a time-varying matrix as follows:
div.formula: Definition 3. Given a matrix function H : [0, T ]  → R p×q , its ∞- norm is defined by ‖H‖ ∞ = sup t∈[0,T ] ‖H(t)‖,(31)
div.p: where ‖ • ‖ is the induced matrix norm associated with the vector norm used in Definition 2.
Theorem 1. Consider the multi-agent system (1), and let the distributed iterative learning scheme (15) be applied. If there exists
div.formula: a matrix Γ ∈ R m 1 ×m satisfying ‖I -EL k G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ ∞ < 1, ∀k ∈ M,(32)
div.p: then y i (t) converges to zero monotonically as i → ∞ for all t ∈ [0, T ], and the desired formation (2) is asymptotically realized.

Proof. It should be pointed out that the vector and matrix norms in the proof are taken to be compatible, as stated in Definitions 2 and 3. Since f (x i,j (t)) is a Lipschitz continuous functional in terms of x i,j (t), there exists a Lipschitz constant k f such that
from which it can be easily verified that
In addition, by ( 22), there exists a finite scalar k Φ > 0 such that
div.formula: k Φ = sup ∀i,τ ∈[0,T ] ‖Φ i (τ )‖ = sup k∈M,τ ∈[0,T ] ‖D + (EL k ⊗ B(τ )Γ )‖.
div.p: Then, taking norms to the Eq. ( 29) results in
div.formula: ‖y i+1 (t)‖ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ • ‖y i (t)‖ + ∫ t 0 ‖E‖ • k f ‖x i+1 (τ ) -x i (τ )‖dτ + ∫ t 0 k Φ ‖G‖ • ‖y i (τ )‖dτ .
div.p: Multiplying the above inequality with e -λt (λ > 0) leads to
div.formula: e -λt ‖y i+1 (t)‖ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ • e -λt ‖y i (t)‖ + k f ‖E‖ ∫ t 0 e -λt ‖x i+1 (τ ) -x i (τ )‖dτ + k Φ ‖G‖ ∫ t 0 e -λt ‖y i (τ )‖dτ = ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ • e -λt ‖y i (t)‖ + k f ‖E‖ ∫ t 0 e λ(τ -t) e -λτ

-x i (τ )‖dτ + k Φ ‖G‖ ∫ t 0 e λ(τ -t) e -λτ ‖y i (τ )‖dτ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ • ‖y i ‖ λ + (k f ‖E‖ • ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ + k Φ ‖G‖ • ‖y i ‖ λ ) ∫ t 0 e λ(τ -t) dτ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ ∞ • ‖y i ‖ λ + (k f ‖E‖ • ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ + k Φ ‖G‖ • ‖y i ‖ λ ) • 1 -e -λT λ ,(35)
div.p: where the definition of λ-norm (30) is applied in the third step.
Again, combining inequality (35) with (30) yields
div.formula: ‖y i+1 ‖ λ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ ∞ • ‖y i ‖ λ + (k f ‖E‖ • ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ + k Φ ‖G‖ • ‖y i ‖ λ ) • o(λ -1 ) (36) with o(λ -1 ) = 1 -e -λT λ .
div.p: Due to ( 12) and ( 16), we get
div.formula: x i+1 (t) -x i (t) = ∫ t 0 [F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ + ∫ t 0 (-L σ i (τ ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ )ė i (τ )dτ = ∫ t 0 [F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ -(L σ i (t) ⊗ B(t)Γ )e i (t) + ∫ t 0 Ψ i (τ )e i (τ )dτ ,
div.p: where Ψ i (τ ) = D + (L σ i (τ ) ⊗ B(τ )Γ ). Further, similar to the proving process of Eq. ( 28), it can be proved that
div.formula: x i+1 (t) -x i (t) = ∫ t 0 [F (x i+1 (τ )) -F (x i (τ ))]dτ -(L σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ )y i (t) + ∫ t 0 Ψ i (τ )(G ⊗ I m )y i (τ )dτ .(37)
div.p: By the proof of inequality (36), one can take λ-norm directly to the Eq. ( 37) to obtain
div.formula: ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ ≤ o(λ -1 )k f ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ + k ∆ ‖y i ‖ λ + o(λ -1 )k Ψ ‖G‖ • ‖y i ‖ λ (38) with k ∆ = sup k∈M,t∈[0,T ] ‖L k G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ and k Ψ = sup ∀i,τ ∈[0,T ] ‖Ψ i (τ )‖ = sup k∈M,τ ∈[0,T ] ‖D + (L k ⊗ B(τ )Γ )‖. From (38), it follows at once that ‖x i+1 -x i ‖ λ ≤ k ∆ + o(λ -1 )k Ψ ‖G‖ 1 -o(λ -1 )k f ‖y i ‖ λ .(39)
div.p: Substituting (39) into (36) results in
div.formula: ‖y i+1 ‖ λ ≤ ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ ∞ • ‖y i ‖ λ + o(λ -1 )  k f ‖E‖ • k ∆ + o(λ -1 )k Ψ ‖G‖ 1 -o(λ -1 )k f + k Φ ‖G‖  ‖y i ‖ λ . (40
div.p: Note that o(λ -1 ) < Hurwitz stable since the interaction graph G k has a spanning tree for ∀k ∈ M. Therefore, the condition (32) can be usually satisfied by designing an appropriate gain matrix Γ in the scheme (15).
For the system (1) with a constant input matrix B, the following corollary is straightforward according to Theorem 1 and Schur complement formula.

Corollary 1. Consider the multi-agent system (1) with B(t) ≡ B, and let the distributed iterative learning scheme (15) be applied. If there exists a matrix Γ ∈ R m 1 ×m satisfying the linear matrix inequality (LMI)
div.formula: [ -I I -EL k G ⊗ BΓ (I -EL k G ⊗ BΓ ) T -I ] < 0 (41)
div.p: for ∀k ∈ M, then y i (t) converges to zero as i → ∞ for all t ∈ [0, T ],
and the desired formation (2) is asymptotically achieved.

div.head: Simulation results
div.p: To illustrate the obtained results, iterative learning scheme (15) is applied to a network of four agents described by (1), with T = 10,
and x j (t) = [x j1 (t) x j2 (t)] T ∈ R 2 representing the position of agent j. For simplicity, the interaction graph is assumed to be undirected and switch arbitrarily within the graph set
div.formula: G s = {G 1 , G 2 , G 3 , G 4 } as
div.p: shown in Fig. 1. The desired relative states, indicating the formation of four agents, are given by Due to Corollary 1, one can determine the gain matrix Γ by solving LMIs in the form of (41), and obtain the D-type distributed iterative learning scheme (15). To apply (15), the zero initial control input is adopted, i.e., u 0 (t) = 0 for t ∈ [0, 10]. Fig. 2 shows the state error trajectories of four agents e i,j (t) = [e i,j(1) (t) e i,j(2) (t)] T (j = 1, 2, 3, 4) at different iteration i, from which it is clear that all agents asymptotically reach consensus on their state errors over time interval [0, 10] as the iteration index i increases. This means that the multi-agent system can maintain the desired formation described by (42) during the whole considered time interval. Furthermore, to measure the formation accuracy quantitatively, the disagreement among all agents on their state errors are defined by z i (t) = (L c ⊗ I m )e i (t), where i is the iteration index, and L c ∈ R n×n is a symmetric matrix with diagonal elements n-1 n and other elements -1 n . Note that z i (t) = 0 if and only if all agents achieve the exact consensus on their state errors. Therefore, ‖z i (t)‖ 2 = (  T 0 z T i (t)z i (t)dt) 1/2 reflects the formation error by evaluating the disagreement energy of state errors. On this basis, Fig. 3 exhibits the formation performance of four agents at the first 60 iterations by setting the Y -axis as ‖z i (t)‖ 2 . Obviously, the formation error converges to zero as a function of iteration.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, the accurate formation control problem has been addressed for switching networks of multiple agents with unknown nonlinear dynamics by the ILC approach. Based on a series of transformations, the formation problem was equivalently converted into a stability control problem over finite time intervals, to which a distributed iterative learning scheme was proposed. Then a convergence analysis of the obtained ILC process was developed to ensure that the multi-agent system could always keep the desired formation during the whole motion process. This paper highlights the potential applications of ILC theory to the distributed cooperative control of multi-agent systems.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 2.Asymptotically consensus of four agents on their state errors as iteration increases.

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Convergence of state errors (i.e., formation errors) vs. iteration number.

1/λ. Then by selecting sufficiently large λ, we get the convergence condition as ‖I -EL σ i (t) G ⊗ B(t)Γ ‖ ∞ < 1, ∀σ i (t), which can be guaranteed by (32), since all L σ i (t) belong to the finite set {L 1 , . . . , L M }. This completes the proof.
